moves.1. e4: Perhaps hoping to draw his opponent into a Ruy Lopez, where Canal's own theoretical innovation is now immortalized as the Canal Variation.
moves.1... d5: The amateur starts the fireworks immediately, choosing the aggressive, if not entirely theoretically sound, Center Counter Defense.
moves.2... Qxd5: The immediate recapture, exposing the Queen to danger.
moves.3. Nc3: Development with gain of time, attacking the Queen.
moves.3... Qa5: The usual move, setting up a potential pin on the White QN.
moves.4. d4: Canal's move activates the pin but seizes central space.
moves.4... c6: Creating a potential line of retreat for the Q.
moves.5. Nf3: Canal resumes his development and guards the QP.
moves.5... Bg4: The amateur develops another piece and establishes a second pin.
moves.6. Bf4: Canal seizes an open diagonal for his Bishop.
moves.6... e6: The amateur opens a diagonal for the development of *his* Bishop.
moves.8. Qxf3: Canal completes the exchange and clears the way for potential Q-side castling.
moves.8... Bb4: The amateur develops a piece and adds force to the pin on the QN.
moves.9. Be2: Canal clears the last minor piece off his first rank.
moves.9... Nd7: The amateur prepares to castle Queen-side.
moves.10. a3: Now Canal "puts the question" to the other Black Bishop.
moves.10... O-O-O: The amateur sees that 11 PxB can be answered by 11...QxR ch, and ignores the threat in favor of castling.
moves.12. Kd2: Canal could have interposed with his B or N at Q1, but prefers the "two-Rook sacrifice".
moves.12... Qxh1: The amateur, naturally, accepts the sacrifice. He silently tells Canal, "Prove it!"
moves.13. Qxc6+: Another sacrifice! First both Rooks and now the Queen.
moves.14. Ba6#: Who needs Rooks or Queens when you can mate with Bishops? Well done by Canal.
